text.beginner: Dry leaves crunch under your boots as you walk down the dark street.
text.intermediate: Dry leaves crunch under your boots as you walk down the dark street.
text.advanced: Dry leaves crunch beneath your boots as you move through the darkened street.

text.beginner: The neighborhood is silent. Every house has its lights turned off.
text.intermediate: The neighborhood is silent. Every house has its lights turned off.
text.advanced: The neighborhood is silent, every house dark and lifeless.

text.beginner: You can still smell the strong scent of kerosene on your uniform.
text.intermediate: You can still smell the strong scent of kerosene on your uniform.
text.advanced: The sharp scent of kerosene still clings stubbornly to your uniform.

text.beginner: You turn a corner and stop. A girl is standing in the moonlight in a white dress.
text.intermediate: You turn a corner and stop. A girl stands in the moonlight, dressed in white.
text.advanced: You round a corner and halt. A girl stands motionless in the moonlight, dressed in white.

text.beginner: Of course, you’re a new neighbor, aren’t you?
text.intermediate: Of course, you’re a new neighbor, aren’t you?
text.advanced: Of course—you’re a new neighbor, aren’t you?

text.beginner: And you must be... the fireman.
text.intermediate: And you must be... the fireman.
text.advanced: And you must be… the fireman.

text.beginner: She looks at the orange salamander on your arm and the 451 on your helmet.
text.intermediate: She studies the orange salamander on your arm and the number 451 on your helmet.
text.advanced: Her gaze lingers on the orange salamander stitched on your arm and the 451 on your helmet.

text.beginner: How oddly you say that.
text.intermediate: How oddly you say that.
text.advanced: You say that in a very odd way.

text.beginner: I’d have known it with my eyes shut. The smell of kerosene...
text.intermediate: I’d have known it with my eyes shut. The smell of kerosene...
text.advanced: I’d have known it with my eyes closed—the smell of kerosene gives it away.

text.beginner: My wife always complains. You never wash it off completely. Kerosene is perfume to me.
text.intermediate: My wife always complains. You never wash it off completely. Kerosene is perfume to me.
text.advanced: My wife always complains. You can never wash it off completely. To me, kerosene is perfume.

text.beginner: Does it really seem like that?
text.intermediate: Does it seem like that, really?
text.advanced: Does it truly feel that way to you?

text.beginner: Of course. Why not?
text.intermediate: Of course. Why not?
text.advanced: Of course it does. Why wouldn’t it?

text.beginner: She turns toward the houses. You find yourself walking beside her.
text.intermediate: She turns toward the houses, and you begin walking beside her.
text.advanced: She turns toward the darkened houses, and without realizing it, you walk alongside her.

text.beginner: I'm Clarisse McClellan. I'm seventeen and I'm crazy.
text.intermediate: I'm Clarisse McClellan. I'm seventeen and I'm crazy.
text.advanced: I'm Clarisse McClellan. I'm seventeen—and I'm considered quite crazy.

text.beginner: I like to smell things and look at things and sometimes stay up all night.
text.intermediate: I like to smell things and look at things and sometimes stay up all night.
text.advanced: I like to observe, to smell things, to look closely—and sometimes I stay up all night.

text.beginner: Do you ever read the books you burn?
text.intermediate: Do you ever read any of the books you burn?
text.advanced: Do you ever read any of the books before you burn them?

text.beginner: That's against the law!
text.intermediate: That's against the law!
text.advanced: That’s against the law.

text.beginner: Did firemen ever put fires out long ago?
text.intermediate: Is it true firemen once put fires out instead of starting them?
text.advanced: Is it true that firemen once extinguished fires rather than starting them?

text.beginner: Strange. I heard houses used to burn by accident.
text.intermediate: Strange. I heard houses used to burn by accident.
text.advanced: Strange. I’ve heard that houses once burned by accident.

text.beginner: Why are you laughing?
text.intermediate: Why are you laughing?
text.advanced: Why are you laughing?

text.beginner: I don’t know. You answer too fast.
text.intermediate: I don't know. You answer without thinking.
text.advanced: I don’t know. You answer before thinking about what I’ve asked.

text.beginner: You stop walking. You feel uncomfortable.
text.intermediate: You stop walking, unsure why you feel irritated.
text.advanced: You stop walking, unsettled by her words though unsure why.

text.beginner: Good night!
text.intermediate: Good night!
text.advanced: Good night.

text.beginner: Are you happy?
text.intermediate: Are you happy?
text.advanced: Are you happy?

text.beginner: She is gone. You stand alone in the night.
text.intermediate: She is already gone, running into the night.
text.advanced: She is already gone, vanishing into the moonlit night.

options.text: No. Houses have always been fireproof.
